body_text.text: and hCD26/HKU4-RBD-E541A pairs, because the hCD26 protein of ＞200 μM tends to precipitate on the chip. Therefore, the dissociation constants for these two binding pairs were determined as ＞400 μM based on the kinetic data. Figure S3 . A side-by-side comparison of the HKU4-and MERS-RBD structure, Related to Figure 1 . The secondary-structure elements are labeled. In comparison to MERS-RBD (magenta for the core subdomain and green for the external subdomain), HKU4-RBD (orange for the core subdomain and cyan for the external subdomain) lacks an α-helix (α1) and two small strands (β2 and β11) in the core subdomain, and is devoid of a 3 10 helix (η4) in the external subdomain. In addition, the helix preceding strand β3 exhibits characteristics of a 3 10 helix (η') in HKU4-RBD, rather than being α-helical (α3) as in MERS-RBD. These elements are highlighted by marking with arrows. from the data and the model, respectively. R free is the R factor for a subset (5%) of reflections that was selected prior to refinement calculations and was not included in the refinement. d Ramachandran plots were generated by using the program PROCHECK. The van der Waal (vdw) contacts and H-bond interactions at the HKU4-RBD/hCD26 interface were characterized. The HKU4-RBD residues locating within a 4.5-Å distance from the receptor were selected and listed in column 1. The number of inter-molecule contacts contributed by, the side-chain and/or main-chain H-bonds observed for and the location of each interface residues were listed in columns 2-4, respectively. "-" indicates that no H-bond was observed, and the number of H-bonds contributed by the indicated residues were presented in parentheses. Residues K506 and E541, which afford both side-chain H-bond interactions and multi-vdw contacts, are highlighted.
The constructs used for protein expression and purification were individually cloned by insertion of the coding sequences for HKU4-RBD (S residues E372-Y611,
The proteins used for crystallization and SPR experiments were prepared using the Bac-to-Bac
The monomer of HKU4-RBD was mixed with hCD26 at a 1:1 stoichiometry, and crystallization trials were performed by sitting drop vapor diffusion at 4ºC .
body_text.section: Crystallization, Data Collection, and Structure Determination

body_text.text: Diffractable crystals of the complex were finally obtained in a condition consisting of 0.1 M sodium citrate, pH 5.5 and 15% PEG 6000 with a protein concentration of 15 mg/ml. Crystals were cryoprotected in reservoir solution containing 20% (v/v) glycerol and flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen. Diffraction data were collected at Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF) BL17U and processed with HKL2000 (Otwinowski and Minor, 1997) .
body_text.section: Crystallization, Data Collection, and Structure Determination

body_text.text: The complex structure was solved by the molecular replacement module of PHASER (Read, 2001) from the CCP4 program suite (Collaborative Computational Project, 1994) , with the previously reported complex structure of MERS-RBD/hCD26 (PDB code: 4KR0) as the search model. Restrained rigid-body refinement with REFMAC5 (CCP4 suite) and manual model building with COOT (Emsley and Cowtan, 2004) were then performed. Further rounds of refinement were then done with Phenix.refine (Adams et al., 2010) . During model building and refinement, the program of PROCHECK (Laskowski et al., 1993) was used to monitor the stereochemistry of the structure. The data collection and structure refinement statistics were summarized in Table 1 . The structural figures were generated using PyMOL (http://www.pymol.org/).
body_text.section: Crystallization, Data Collection, and Structure Determination

body_text.text: The secondary structure elements were determined using the ESPript (Gouet et al., 1999) algorithm.

body_text.text: The BiAcore experiments were carried out at 25ºC using a BIAcore 3000 machine with CM5 chips (GE Healthcare). All proteins used in the experiment were exchanged

Human hepatocellular carcinoma Huh7 was used for the binding test. Huh7 cells were suspended in PBS and incubated with individual mouse Fc-fusion proteins or a goat anti-hCD26 antibody (R&D system) at 37º C for 30 min. The cells were then washed and further incubated at 37º C for 30 min with an anti-mIgG/PE or an anti-goat IgG/TRITC (R&D system) antibody. After washing, the cells were analyzed using BD FACSCalibur.

For the binding-blocking assay, Huh7 cells were incubated with an anti-hCD26 or an anti-Flag antibody (Sigma) at 20 μg/ml or with 1 μg/μl of purified hCD26 or hACE2 ecto-domain protein at 37º C for 30 min before the addition of HKU4-RBD-mFc.

For the BHK cell-staining, the cells were transfected with pEGFP-C1-CD26 or a control plasmid pEGFP-C1, harvested 48 h post-transfection, and stained with individual mouse Fc-fusion proteins as described above. The cells incubated only with the anti-mIgG/PE antibody were used as the negative controls.

HEK 293T cells were used to package the pseudovirus particles. pCAGGS-HKU4-S or pCAGGS-MERS-S was co-transfected with a plasmid encoding an Env-defective, For the antibody blocking assay, Huh7 cells were first incubated with the anti-hCD26 antibody at the indicated concentrations. The cells were then infected with BatCoV HKU4 pseudoviruses treated with 10 μg/ml of trypsin, incubated and tested for the luciferase activity as described above.

FIGREF0.text: The gel filtration chromatographs of HKU4-RBD and HKU5-RBD, Related to Figure 3. The indicated proteins were passed through a Superdex 200 (10/300 GL) column, and the resultant profiles of absorbance at 280 nm were recorded. The pooled proteins were further analyzed by SDS-PAGE, the separation profile of which was presented as an inset figure. The 31 and 45 kDa molecular weight standards are highlighted. Lane 1, protein molecular weight marker. Lane 2, pooled protein. (A) HKU4-RBD. (B) HKU5-RBD.

FIGREF1.text: The saturation profiles for the indicated binding pairs characterized in the SPR assay, Related to Figure 3. (A) hCD26 to HKU4-RBD. (B) hCD26 to HKU4-RBD-K506A. (C) hCD26 to HKU4-RBD-E541A. (D) hCD26 to HKU4-RBD-SKL. Saturation can not be fulfilled for the hCD26/HKU4-RBD-K506A

FIGREF2.text: accession number: EF065505), HKU5-RBD (S residues E375-Y604, accession number: EF065509), MERS-RBD (S residues E367-Y606, accession number: JX869059), SARS-RBD (S residues R306-F527, accession number: NC_004718), hCD26 (residues S39-P766, accession number: NP_001926), hACE2 (residues S19-D615, accession number: BAJ21180) and the HKU4-RBD mutants including HKU4-RBD-K506A, HKU4-RBD-E541A and HKU4-RBD-SKL (S540W, K547R and L558W) into the EcoRI and XhoI restriction sites of pFastBac1 vector.For each protein, an N-terminal gp67 signal peptide(Zhang et al., 2010) and a C-terminal hexa-His were added to facilitate protein secretion and purification.To prepare the Fc chimeric proteins, the fragments encoding MERS-RBD, HKU4-RBD and HKU5-RBD were fused 5'-terminally to a fragment coding for mouse Fc domain and ligated into the pCAGGS expression vector via the EcoRI and XhoI restriction sites. All fusion proteins were linked to the signal peptide of the MERS-CoV S protein.The construct pEGFP-C1-CD26 used for FACS was cloned by insertion of the full-length coding sequence of hCD26 into pEGFP-C1 at the restriction sites of XhoI and SmaI.The plasmid pCAGGS-MERS-S used for MERS-CoV-pseudovirus production was constructed by ligation of the full-length coding sequence of MERS-CoV S into the pCAGGS vector using EcoR I and Sma I restriction sites. The coding sequence for the S protein of BatCoV HKU4 was codon-optimized for mammalian expression, synthesized and sub-cloned into the pCAGGS vector using EcoRI and XhoI restriction sites by Generay Biotech Co., Ltd, yielding the construct of pCAGGS-HKU4-S. The two S proteins were 3'-flanked by a flag tag to test the expression of the protein.

FIGREF3.text: baculovirus expression system (Invitrogen). The constructed pFastBac1 was transformed into DH10Bac competent cells to get the recombinant Bacmid. Then the Bacmid was transfected into Sf9 to get the baculovirus stock. Sf9 was then used to amplify the baculoviruses, and High5 cells were used to express the protein. The supernatant of High5 was collected 48 h post-infection and passed through a 5 ml HisTrap HP column (GE Healthcare). The proteins bound to HisTrap were then detached by gradient concentrations of imidazole. The fractions containing the target protein was determined by SDS-PAGE. The samples were then pooled and further purified by a Superdex 200 column (GE Healthcare) with the buffer of 20 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0) and 150 mM NaCl. The pooled HKU4-RBD and HKU5-RBD proteins were further characterized by analytical gel filtration using a calibrated Superdex 200 (10/300 GL) column (GE Healthcare). The Fc fusion proteins were expressed in HEK-293T cells by transient transfection. Cells were washed with PBS twice 6 h post-transfection, and then cultured in fresh DMEM. The cell culture was collected four days post transfection. After centrifugation at 2000 rpm for 5 min, the supernatant was mixed with two volumes of the binding buffer containing 1.5 M glycine, 3 M NaCl, pH 8.9 and filtered with a 0.22-μm filter. The mixture passed through the HiTrap rProtein A FF (1ml, GE Healthcare) column at 1 ml/min. The bound protein was detached from the column by 0.1 M sodium citrate, pH 4.5. The elution was adjusted to the neutral pH by adding 100 μl of 1 M Tris-HCl, pH 9.0 per milliliter and further purified by gel filtration. The protein was finally buffered with PBS, concentrated to about 1 mg/ml, and stored at -80º C before further usage.

FIGREF4.text: to the HBS-EP buffer consisting of 10 mM HEPES, pH7.4, 150 mM NaCl and 0.005% v/v Tween 20. The aforementioned RBD proteins were immobilized on the chip at about 1000 response units (RUs). Gradient concentrations of hCD26 (ranging from 0.195-200 μM) or hACE2 (ranging from 0.039-20 μM) were then injected at 30 μl/min. After each cycle, the sensor surface was re-generated using 7 μl of 10 mM NaOH. Measurements from the reference flow cell (immobilized with BSA) were subtracted from experimental values. The binding kinetics was analyzed with the software BIAevaluation Version 4.1 using the 1:1 Langumuir binding and/or the steady state affinity models.

TABREF2.text: luciferase-expressing HIV-1 genome (pNL4-3.luc.RE)(He et al., 2004) into 293T cells. Five hours post-transfection, the medium was changed to fresh DMEM containing 10% FBS. The next morning, cells were washed with PBS twice, and fresh DMEM was added. The supernatant containing the pseudovirus particles was collected 48 h post-transfection. The harvested supernatant containing virus particles pseudotyped with MERS-CoV S was directly applied to the infection assay, whereas the pseudoviruses embedding BatCoV HKU4 S was digested with trypsin before the infection test. The supernatant was first concentrated 10 times with a 30 kD-cutoff ultracentrifugation tube. Trypsin was then added at the indicated concentrations (2.5, 5, 10, 20 and 40 μg/ml). After a 40 h-digestion, 0.5% FBS was added to inactivate the trypsin. The cell-infection assay was performed with Huh7 cells, which were first incubated with the indicated pseudovirus for 5 h, washed with PBS, and then cultured with DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS. The luciferase activity was determined 48 h post-infection using a GloMax 96 Microplate luminometer (Promega).
